displayed_text: Patient: No. You’ve got it all. Doctor: So I’m going to put Bell’s palsy on here. You said it’s lopsided? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And you’ve had, not had any issues with depression in the past or anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Any acid reflux? Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: Ever have a seizure? Patient: No. Doctor: Stroke? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Sleep apnea?

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Wow! Small world. Maybe my husband was in training in radiation oncology. Maybe you know him. Family Member: I think so. Doctor: Yeah because (laughs) Patient: Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: You know that was twenty some years ago so that’s probably about right. Family Member: That is. Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, alright, so let me check with D__ if your PSA came back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We are going to do one last ditch effort. I don’t know what’s taking so long even for the labs today. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: So if the placebo is a non-starter for you, then we skipped that as an option. But again just thinking broad terms first before we get into those details. Just thinking in broad terms so push off the for hormone therapy for a while and do a targeted radiotherapy instead. Or whether you feel that you just want to go ahead and give the hormone therapy to increase the chances of that lasting as long as possible or do some remission that lasts Patient: And yeah, but the way I’m going, I’d be the one in three. (laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I had it the other way I would have won the lottery. Doctor: I hear you. I hear you. Patient: So thank you very much. Healthcare Professional: So uhm, how are you feeling? You got a lot of side effects from this. Patient: Well, uhm, with me as far as the medication I was on the worst part of it was I think the joints at first, but then it became progressively better. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Patient: To where once you know I guess I was on the medication long enough, that totally disappeared. But it for a while there it was just crazy. Healthcare Professional: You still have it. Right. Do you still feel it at all or?

Patient: I thought you said the scans didn’t… Family Member: That’s what you said last month. Healthcare Professional: Last time they had the prelim report, but… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So one of the areas and again like I said I don’t know what to make of this because it is on the bone scan. I thought I – did we talk about this? Okay. Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say. Doctor: Okay, well my sense is you know he and I can talk about sort of when’s the right time to get new pictures, and the lung stuff is interesting because is it just cancer in your lung that causing this gasping, this wheezing? Patient: He doesn’t think so. Doctor: I don’t think so either, but you’d have to rule that out because that can complicate sometimes clinical trials- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because using experimental therapies in somebody who’s got something else going wrong that’s not the cancer or the therapy- Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: …and then we’re gonna do some evaluations, we’re gonna make some decisions and we’ll… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …we’ll formalize a plan and we’ll go from there. Doctor: Yes. And then you go on vacation, when you come back we’ll have more data. Patient: Sure. Doctor: And then we have multitude of options including standard pills… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …standard chemo, and/or clinical studies of which there are several. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Good. Doctor: So I’m gonna have M____ come in… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left.

Patient: …you had another patient that his insurance wouldn’t cover it until… Doctor: It’s the same thing. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Until you actually have a problem and then they go oh look he’s got a problem, okay we’ll give it to you now. I know. Patient: That’s terrible. Doctor: It’s terrible. So… Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation,

Patient: Well not really. I’m still taking it. Healthcare Professional: No he’s not. He’s still taking – Doctor: Oh you are still taking it. Healthcare Professional: He has to stop Doctor: No you have to stop it for a week anyway before the biopsy. Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said.

Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah. Doctor: It’s in the, um – Family Member: We can have that. Patient: Test results? Doctor: Well, for me, it’s in a tab called “media.” I don’t know what you have access to. Family Member: But it’s the only thing that came up in, in that genetic testing. Doctor: Right. So they, they look at, they look at about thirty genes that are key genes for cancer.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that?

Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just….

Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine. Doctor: Okay. And you’ve been emailing me? Who’s been writing the pain people? Who’s been doing that for you? Patient: What? Doctor: When you need a refill. Patient: Huh, I call R___. Doctor: Okay. But then they need a doctor to sign it. Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need Doctor: That kind of stuff I can help you with uh if you need a refill, um. Patient: Okay. When I take the ibuprofen, then I might only have to take one of the morphine. You know what I’m saying? More during the day, if the pain coming back just take the ibuprofen and I won’t need morphine. (Coughs) Doctor: So I have a known history, and your hepatitis C, they treated it. Right? Patient: No. It’s in, not, huh, you know how you, huh, you go get this medicine for it? They say I’m not in that category to get anything for it. Doctor: Okay. So your, your hepatitis C isn’t serious and hasn’t, huh, caused any-? Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. If that’s positive, then that would be this one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if it’s negative, it could be that one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or, if it was positive, you could still do that one. Um. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That one doesn’t care. Patient: Right. If everything looks good, I’d like to come back on the nineteenth. Doctor: Right. So, if we communicate by MyChart or I_ and I will communicate with you about stopping the drugs, if you decide, but I want you to take a look at it Patient: Okay. Doctor: More, more.
